attributes.title: Programmatic Construction of Symbolic Reaction Systems

children: Programmatic Construction of Symbolic Reaction Systems
While the DSL provides a simple interface for creating
s, it can often be convenient to build or augment a
programmatically. In this tutorial we show how to build the repressilator model of the
tutorial directly using symbolic variables, and then summarize the basic API functionality for accessing information stored within
and then define symbolic variables for each parameter and species in the system (the latter corresponding to a

@parameters α, K, n, δ, γ, β, μ;
@variables t, m₁(t), m₂(t), m₃(t), P₁(t), P₂(t), P₃(t);
Note, each species is declared as a variable that is a function of time!
Next we specify the chemical reactions that comprise the system using Catalyst

rxs = [Reaction(hillr(P₃,α,K,n), nothing, [m₁]),
       Reaction(hillr(P₁,α,K,n), nothing, [m₂]),
       Reaction(hillr(P₂,α,K,n), nothing, [m₃]),
       Reaction(δ, [m₁], nothing),
       Reaction(γ, nothing, [m₁]),
       Reaction(δ, [m₂], nothing),
       Reaction(γ, nothing, [m₂]),
       Reaction(δ, [m₃], nothing),
       Reaction(γ, nothing, [m₃]),
       Reaction(β, [m₁], [m₁,P₁]),
       Reaction(β, [m₂], [m₂,P₂]),
       Reaction(β, [m₃], [m₃,P₃]),
       Reaction(μ, [P₁], nothing),
       Reaction(μ, [P₂], nothing),
       Reaction(μ, [P₃], nothing)]
. Finally, we are ready to construct our
. A name must always be specified when directly constructing a
(the DSL will auto-generate one if left out). Using
causes the name of the system to be the same as the name of the variable storing the system. Alternatively, one can use the
We can check that this is the same model as the one we defined via the DSL as follows (this requires that we use the same names for rates, species and the system)

repressilator2 = @reaction_network repressilator begin
    hillr(P₃,α,K,n), ∅ --> m₁
    hillr(P₁,α,K,n), ∅ --> m₂
    hillr(P₂,α,K,n), ∅ --> m₃
    (δ,γ), m₁ <--> ∅
    (δ,γ), m₂ <--> ∅
    (δ,γ), m₃ <--> ∅
    β, m₁ --> m₁ + P₁
    β, m₂ --> m₂ + P₂
    β, m₃ --> m₃ + P₃
    μ, P₁ --> ∅
    μ, P₂ --> ∅
    μ, P₃ --> ∅
end α K n δ γ β μ
repressilator == repressilator2
In the example above all the specified
s were first or zero order. The three-argument form of
implicitly assumes all species have a stoichiometric coefficient of one, i.e. for substrates

# rate, S₁ + ... + Sₘ --> P₁ + ... + Pₙ
Reaction(rate, [S₁,...,Sₘ], [P₁,...,Pₙ])

# rate, S₁ + ... + Sₘ --> ∅
Reaction(rate, [S₁,...,Sₘ], nothing)

# rate, ∅ --> P₁ + ... + Pₙ
Reaction(rate, nothing, [P₁,...,Pₙ])
To allow for other stoichiometric coefficients we also provide a five argument form

# rate, α₁*S₁ + ... + αₘ*Sₘ --> β₁*P₁ + ... + βₙ*Pₙ
Reaction(rate, [S₁,...,Sₘ], [P₁,...,Pₙ], [α₁,...,αₘ], [β₁,...,βₙ])

# rate, α₁*S₁ + ... + αₘ*Sₘ --> ∅
Reaction(rate, [S₁,...,Sₘ], nothing, [α₁,...,αₘ], nothing)

# rate, ∅ --> β₁*P₁ + ... + βₙ*Pₙ
Reaction(rate, nothing, [P₁,...,Pₙ], nothing, [β₁,...,βₙ])
Finally, we note that the rate constant,
above, does not need to be a constant or fixed function, but can be a general symbolic expression:
user_functions) for info on using general user-specified functions for the rate constant.
In some cases one wants to build reactions incrementally, as in the repressilator example, but it would be nice to still have a short hand as in the
DSL. In this case one can construct individual reactions using the
For example, the repressilator reactions could also have been constructed like
Note, there are a few differences when using the
macro to specify one reaction versus using the full
. First, only one reaction (i.e. a single forward arrow type) can be used, i.e. reversible arrows like
will not work (since they define more than one reaction). Second, the

macro must try to infer which symbols are species versus parameters, and uses the heuristic that anything appearing in the rate expression is a parameter. Coefficients in the reaction part are also inferred as parameters, while rightmost symbols (i.e. substrates and products) are inferred as species. As such, the following are equivalent
This behavior is the reason that in the repressilator example above we pre-declared
as variables, and then used them via interpolating their values into the rate law expressions using
in the macro. This ensured they were properly treated as species and not parameters. See the
provides a large variety of functionality for querying properties of a reaction network. Here we go over a few of the most useful basic functions. Given the
is mass action, i.e. the rate does not depend on

# Catalyst.hillr(P₃(t), α, K, n), ∅ --> m₁
rx1 = reactions(repressilator)[1]
ismassaction(rx1,repressilator)
Similarly, we can determine which species a reaction's rate law will depend on like

rn = @reaction_network begin
       k*W, 2X + 3Y --> 5Z + W
     end k
dependents(reactions(rn)[1], rn)
Basic stoichiometry matrices can be obtained from a
entry gives the corresponding stoichiometric coefficient of species
Finally, we can directly access fields of individual reactions like
for much more detail on the various querying and analysis functions provided by Catalyst.
